Key Arguments: The bill is undemocratic and assumes Australians cannot determine truth for themselves.
Freedom of speech is a fundamental human right that enables critical thinking and open debate.
Censorship blames the informer for the actions of the recipient and can be used to suppress dissent.
The development of a code of practice by the industry excludes the general public.
No government or agency has a monopoly on truth, and perceptions of truth evolve over time.
Notable Quotes: This bill must not go ahead, and is at its core undemocratic.
Freedom of speech is not only a fundamental human right, it affords Australians the ability to practice critical thinking, debate about issues openly, and come to their own conclusions.
No one government or agency has a monopoly on truth. Our perception of truth evolves over time with experience.
